title: BBCU F.C.
text:
BBCU Football Club, full name Big Bang Chula United Football Club, () is a defunct <a href="Thailand">Thai</a> professional <a href="association%20football">football</a> club based in <a href="Bangkok">Bangkok</a>, <a href="Thailand">Thailand</a>, owned by Montri Suwannoi. Founded as "Bangtoey Football Team" in 1976, the club changed its name many times, until finally, it became "BBCU" in 2011.
BBCU was one of the most successful Thai football clubs of the late 1990s (under the name of "Sinthana Football Club"). The club has won a <a href="Thai%20League%201">Thai League 1</a> title, 2 <a href="Kor%20Royal%20Cup">Kor Royal Cup</a>s and 1 <a href="Thai%20FA%20Cup">FA Cup</a>. Moreover, during the years in lower divisions, the club has also won a <a href="Regional%20League%20Division%202">Division 2</a> title.
History.
Chulalongkorn University FC is the club based at <a href="Chulalongkorn%20University">Chulalongkorn University</a> in <a href="Bangkok">Bangkok</a>, Thailand. They have played in the <a href="Chula%E2%80%93Thammasat%20Traditional%20Football%20Match">Chula–Thammasat Traditional Football Match</a> since 1934.
In 2004, Chulalongkorn University FC was combined with Sinthana FC (Chula-Sinthana FC) and played in <a href="Thailand%20Division%201%20League">Division 2</a> in 2005 until Chula-Sinthana FC was promoted from <a href="Thailand%20Division%201%20League">Division 1</a> to <a href="Thai%20Premier%20League">Thai Premier League</a> in 2008.
In August of the <a href="Thai%20Premier%20League%202008">2008</a> season, they changed their club name again from "Chula-Sinthana FC" to "Chula United". The Club Director was Kasiti Kamalanavin.
Chula's return to the top flight, <a href="2008%20Thailand%20Premier%20League">2008 Thailand Premier League</a>, ended with them finishing in a creditable 8th position. However they could not build on their first season and were relegated from the <a href="2009%20Thai%20Premier%20League">2009 Thai Premier League</a>.
Despite having two of the three top goalscorers in the <a href="2010%20Thai%20Division%201%20League">2010 Thai Division 1 League</a>, Chula could not bounce back at the first attempt and slumped to a disappointing 10th-placed finish. Chula's striker <a href="Chainarong%20Tathong">Chainarong Tathong</a> topped the <a href="2010%20Thai%20Division%201%20League">2010 Thai Division 1 League</a> goalscoring chart with an impressive 19 goals. Fellow front man <a href="Aron%20da%20Silva">Aron da Silva</a> netted 15 times to be the 3rd top scorer in the league.
In January 2011, the club changed their name to Big Bang Chulalongkorn University FC and relocated to play their home games at the <a href="Thai%20Army%20Sports%20Stadium">Thai Army Sports Stadium</a> on <a href="Vibhavadi%20Rangsit%20Road">Vibhavadi Rangsit Road</a>. The club got off to a flying start and won promotion even though they stuttered in the latter weeks of the season.
The club's venture in the <a href="2012%20Thai%20Premier%20League">2012 Thai Premier League</a> ended with them being relegated after only one season. Home games were played at the sparsely filled 65,000 <a href="Rajamangala%20Stadium">Rajamangala Stadium</a> with an average home attendance of only 939.
In April 2017, the club was dissolved, citing lack of fund as the reason. This team is automatically banned 2 years, If the team decide to come back they will relegated to the lowest tier of professional league.
Stadium.
BBCU have used various stadiums throughout their history:
Season by season record.
Amateur years (1976–1987).
Since Bangtoey Football team was founded in 1976 to compete in Bangkapi Cup tournament, the club had played 11 more years in amateur level before joining the first <a href="Football%20Association%20of%20Thailand">Football Association of Thailand</a>’s competitions season in <a href="Ngor%20Royal%20Cup">Ngor Royal Cup</a> 1998.
Season by season domestic record (2011–present).
